The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasitic animals that are of great interest because of their extreme reduction in body plan and gene content. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we report the results of a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan degeneration was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2 in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. We found that SARS-CoV-2 Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how SARS-CoV-2 evades the host immune response and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat the ongoing pandemic. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of the growing urban population. This will require a 70% increase in global agricultural production. However, the optimum growing temperature for maize is 27 °C, and temperatures above this optimum are associated with yield reductions. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values as the Earth warms. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. (Less)

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large herbivore species in semiarid African savanna. We found that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest overlap in diet. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also highlight the importance of grasses as a food resource in semiarid savanna, and suggest that the use of DNA metabarcoding may be a powerful tool for quantifying diet breadth and composition in large herbivore communities. This approach may be applied to other ecosystems to better understand the role of large herbivores in shaping biodiversity.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Moreover, the length of the crisis is negatively associated with the expected closure of the business. Finally, many small businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. We also assess the take-up rates and business resilience effects of the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This study is of great importance to the scientific community and to the public.

The age of the solar system is one of the most important parameters in astronomy. It is used to determine the age of the universe and to estimate the age of the oldest objects in the universe. However, the age of the solar system is still a matter of debate. We determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar exposure ages of <300 Ma and >1 Ga, which is in agreement with theoretical estimates. The grains were part of aggregates in the interstellar medium, which were probably formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. Furthermore, we show that the bulk of the cosmogenic nuclides in the grains were produced in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This result is important for the age of the solar system and for the age of the universe. It also has implications for the origin of the oldest elements in the universe.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide resources to offspring can increase reproductive output. We find that domestication and all forms of allocare correlate with increased fertility. All forms of provisioning correlate with larger litters without compromising offspring size. The greatest increase we observe in reproductive power is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output and the potential for human intervention in the reproductive rate of animals. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells responsible for the production of myelin in the brain. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in the brain of a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This would be the first disease-modifying treatment for MSA. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls vascular function, including hemostasis, inflammation, and oxygen and nutrient delivery to tissues. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cell types that are connected by a network of communication channels. The network is critical for the endothelium to control vascular function, but the nature of the communication network has been poorly understood. Here, we show that the endothelium is connected by a small-world network, which is a network configuration that is both efficient at transmitting information locally and globally. The small-world network is effective for both local and global communication and is a design that is common in biological systems. This study provides a new perspective on the design of the endothelium and its communication network. It also provides a new perspective on the design of biological networks and their properties. This study may lead to new insights into the control of vascular function and the development of new therapies for vascular diseases.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. The COVIDcast API is our attempt to provide open access to data that can be used to monitor the pandemic and inform policy decisions. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The data are available at https://covidcast.org. The COVIDcast API is available at https://github.com/covidcast/covidcast-api. The R package is available at https://github.com/covidcast/covidcast-r. The Python package is available at https://github.com/covidcast/covidcast-python. The data are also available at https://github.com/covidcast/covidcast-data.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a deeper understanding of the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in human health and disease is still being elucidated, and the potential of the microbiome to produce bioactive compounds has been recognized for many years. However, the potential of the gut microbiome to produce natural products has not been systematically investigated. Here, we report the discovery of a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the gastrointestinal tracts of herbivores. These results provide a foundation for the development of natural products from anaerobic fungi and the potential for the development of new therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats. We further identify an important role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region that is involved in the regulation of social behavior. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design of complex structures with multiple material phases and their seamless collaboration is still challenging. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design composite structures with multiple material phases that can be digitally synthesized and seamlessly collaborate to produce complex and extreme responses. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and exhibit irregular material distributions and complex shapes. The responses of the manufactured structures are accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis strategy can be extended to design structures with multiple material phases and their seamless collaboration for a wide range of applications. This work can provide a new paradigm for the design of mechanical structures with complex and extreme responses. It can also provide a new strategy for the design of mechanical systems with complex and extreme behaviors. The hemoglobin (Hb) system is a key regulator of oxygen transport in the human body. The Hb system is also a target of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway, which is known to regulate the timing of development. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway and that it is expressed in the human fetus and in erythroid cells. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 can reprogram the Hb expression pattern in human erythroid cells, resulting in a fetal-like Hb expression pattern. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a target for chronoregulation of the Hb system in humans. This may have implications for the development of hemoglobinopathies and for the treatment of anemia in aging populations. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the development of fetal hemoglobin in humans.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapeutic strategies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. Mechanistically, this resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1)/monounsaturated fatty acid axis, a central regulator of lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that ferroptosis induction in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation results in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. These findings suggest that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the use of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) is the major treatment for hypertension. However, the mechanisms of LCCB actions on vascular remodeling are not well understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate STIM/ORAI-mediated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs), which is required for LCCB-induced vascular remodeling. Our findings indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our study provides a mechanism of LCCB action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrates that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study may help to improve the safety of LCCBs in clinical practice. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way federal forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP had the intended effect on biodiversity. We found that the policy had a strong influence on forest composition, but the effects on bird populations were more complex. The NWFP halted clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. This will require continued monitoring of bird populations and forest composition. (Less)

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the pharmaceutical industry. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. We used a computational approach to predict the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics toward the ribosome. We then synthesized the top-ranked compounds and tested them in vitro and in vivo. The best compounds were more active than telithromycin, the current standard of care, against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This approach can be used to identify new antibiotics for other pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results suggest that the proposed network architecture is a promising approach for solving many image-processing problems. We believe that the proposed network architecture will be useful for many applications in computer vision and other fields.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. From 800 to 100 ka, a deep, often overfilled lake occupied the basin, indicating a wetter climate, but these highstands were interrupted by prolonged intervals of extreme drought. The use of electronic devices, such as tablets and smartphones, has increased dramatically in the past 50 y. This study shows that the use of such devices in the hours before bedtime has a negative impact on sleep. Specifically, the use of electronic devices phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth’s history. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope compositions of the magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope compositions of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of a 2- to 5-mm diameter spherule indicate that its source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that one or more bolide impacts triggered the YDB. (Read more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of immune responses is well established, but the function of CTLA-4 in the adult mouse is not. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in a variety of autoimmune diseases, including myocarditis, gastritis, pneumonitis, sialadenitis, insulitis, and sialadenitis. These diseases are not fatal, but they are accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. In contrast to congenital deficiency, this is not fatal. We also show that CTLA-4 deletion affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. This may have important implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the phylogeny of beetles and traced the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose using 154 genomes or transcriptomes. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to reduce the time and cost of antibody development and may contribute to the development of a new generation of antibody-based therapeutics. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary biologists and cultural anthropologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Our results indicate that, in the absence of CCE, larger populations do not enhance artifact performance. However, when CCE is present, larger populations do enhance artifact performance, but only under certain specific conditions. These findings have implications for the evolution of technology and the study of cultural evolution. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The apoE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk, whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles affect the accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may contribute to the increased vulnerability of APOE4 to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is consistent with the observation that APOE4 is associated with increased complement activation in the brain. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a sharp boundary. The inner core is a key part of the Earth, and its properties are important for understanding the origin and evolution of the Earth. However, the inner core is a challenging part of the Earth to study because of its high temperature and pressure. In this study, we use a molecular dynamics method to show that the metastable, body-centered, cubic (bcc) phase of iron has a higher nucleation rate than does the stable, hexagonal, close-packed (hcp) phase under inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors associated with marijuana abuse.

The human brain is a massively parallel computer that solves complex problems by processing streams of sensory data in parallel. Here, we show that the most powerful deep learning models for natural language processing also solve this problem in parallel, and that this architecture is associated with better fits to brain and behavioral data. These results provide computational evidence for the idea that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain’s processing of language. They also suggest that the brain may use predictive processing to solve other complex problems, such as speech and face perception. This approach may help to elucidate the neural mechanisms of higher-level cognition.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been plagued by instability. This paper shows that the instability is not due to the difficulty of the problem, but rather due to the lack of a stable algorithm. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they can solve a class of inverse problems. We believe that this work will lead to the development of more stable algorithms for deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including people’s inability to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago that has been widely cited as evidence for this phenomenon. The study’s critical design flaws were not recognized at the time, and the study’s conclusion was subsequently widely accepted. The paper discusses the study’s flaws and how they led to the erroneous conclusion. It also discusses the implications of the study’s flaws for the study of human behavior and decision-making.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause different forms of the disease. The two bacteria are very similar, but they are not the same species. We sequenced the genome of Mycobacterium lepromatosis from a patient with leprosy and compared it with the genome of Mycobacterium leprae. We found that the two bacteria are very similar, but they have also diverged in some important ways. This suggests that they are still evolving and may continue to do so in the future.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the keystones of quantum information theory, where they are at the heart of the foundations of quantum communication and quantum computation. However, the study of the evolution of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is a notoriously difficult task. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is a natural regime for the study of thermodynamics. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions, which are both available for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. We check our result for the entanglement dynamics in the scaling limit against numerical simulations. Our work opens the door to the study of entanglement dynamics in a wide class of systems. It also paves the way for the study of the thermodynamics of isolated quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The only available vaccine, developed by the pharmaceutical company Pfizer and its German partner BioNTech, is not available to the general public. We describe a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is being developed by the University of Oxford and the University of Cape Town. The vaccine is based on a modified version of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which is currently in clinical development. We show that the vaccine is highly protective in hamsters and that it is able to protect against lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. This vaccine candidate could be used in mass vaccination programs to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its history is poorly understood. We developed a mathematical model to understand the history of plague in Europe. Our model suggests that plague was spread by human ectoparasite vectors, such as fleas and lice, rather than by rodents. This is a major change in the current understanding of the history of plague in Europe.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience and cognitive science. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is less understood. We show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also different from that of body size. We also show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is associated with the evolution of cognitive ability. These results have important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. Here we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This may have implications for the development of TRAP1-targeted therapies. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin severes filaments is not known. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin enhances severing of filaments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist. A simple model, which faithfully recapitulates our experimental observations, indicates that the ADF/cofilin-induced twist enhances severing by 100-fold. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our work provides a mechanistic understanding of ADF/cofilin’s function in severing actin filaments. This understanding will be critical to developing new strategies to target ADF/cofilin in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be mediated, at least in part, by the hormone insulin. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on health and for developing strategies to reduce consumption of these beverages. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the island was settled by multiple waves of people from different parts of Africa and Asia. The settlement history is complex, and we found that the island was settled by multiple waves of people from different parts of Africa and Asia. In addition, we found that the island is divided into regions with different genetic patterns, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar was not a homogeneous process. These results are important for understanding the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. They also have implications for the study of human evolution and the origin of agriculture.

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not interacting with the person who is expressing the emotion. This is a form of emotional contagion, and it is well established in laboratory experiments. However, the results of previous experiments are controversial, and some have suggested that emotional contagion is limited to in-person interactions. Our results suggest that emotional contagion can occur over social networks, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences can be a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. These results have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society. The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been known for decades, but the impact of these modifications on protein synthesis has been difficult to study. Here, we show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in an mRNA codon can have a profound effect on translation. We show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can slow translation, increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid incorporation, and increase the rate of peptide synthesis. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can have a significant impact on the rate of protein synthesis. This work provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis and may have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in human disease. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that higher ratings of worthwhile activities are associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better health and fitness, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to the effects of factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, and prosperity. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. This study provides evidence for the importance of a sense of purpose in older age. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in biology, but the extent to which aquatic mammals are constrained by the demands of the aquatic environment remains unclear. Here, we show that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is driven toward a common optimum size and that this optimum size is consistent with the strict energetic demands of the aquatic environment. This work provides a quantitative framework for understanding the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals and suggests that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is driven and confined by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic environment. This work also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of body size in other aquatic organisms.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense the presence of surfaces and to regulate its virulence. This is achieved by a mechanochemical model where the mechanical activity of pili is sensed by a chemosensory system, which in turn regulates the activity of pili. This mechanism is important for the pathogenicity of P. aeruginosa, as it allows the bacteria to sense the presence of surfaces and to regulate its virulence. Our findings thus provide insights into the evolution of bacterial sensing systems and the regulation of bacterial motility and virulence. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has been characterized by the rapid spread of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes disease in humans, and the subsequent development of vaccines and antiviral therapies. However, the potential for SARS-CoV-2 to spread to other animal species has been a source of concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a species that is widely distributed across North America. We also describe the rapid spread of SARS-CoV-2 in deer during the winter months, when human cases are declining. Our findings highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology and evolution of SARS-CoV-2, as well as the potential for the virus to spread to other animal species. This information is critical for developing effective strategies to mitigate the spread of the virus and prevent future outbreaks. (Show more)

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a complex disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, both of which are toxic to neurons. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the presence of Aβ plaques, which are not present in all AD patients. Here, we show that neurons are also involved in the inflammatory process in AD, and that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons is a significant contributor to the immune response. Our findings suggest that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis. This may have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still missing. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the ancient world. Our results suggest that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe predates the earliest evidence in the Near East by at least a century.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular mechanisms that control the concentration of Np4 and the rate at which it is degraded are not well understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove the nucleoside monophosphates capping bacterial RNAs, also removes Np4-capped RNAs. We demonstrate that RppH prefers Np4-capped RNAs as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts, and that the unique manner in which capped substrates bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which bacteria regulate the concentration of alarmones and the rate at which they are degraded. It also suggests that RppH may be a promising target for the development of new antibiotics. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is activated in response to the inflammatory stimulus, it is also impaired, leading to a vicious cycle of immunosuppression and organ failure. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine, a key amino acid, is a key player in the immune dysfunction observed in sepsis. We show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function in sepsis. Our results suggest that citrulline could be a potential therapeutic strategy to improve the clinical outcome of sepsis patients. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of all living organisms on Earth is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems can self-regulate their activity level. SOC systems are characterized by a critical state, where the system is neither too active nor too inactive. In this paper, we study a continuous model of SOC, which is a scaling limit of the sandpile model. We show that this model exhibits a critical state and discuss the connection between our model and pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

The discovery of the antimicrobial activity of NCR peptides in the nodules of Medicago truncatula led to the hypothesis that these peptides might have a role in plant disease resistance. However, the structural basis of antifungal activity and the mode of action of NCR peptides against plant fungal pathogens remained unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the antifungal NCR peptide, which is largely disordered and dynamic. We also show that this peptide exhibits potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and three Fusarium spp. It binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and induces reactive oxygen species in germlings of the fungal pathogen. The antifungal activity of NCR peptides is unique and may be useful for the development of new strategies for the control of plant fungal diseases. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of NCR peptides and demonstrates their potential as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. (Read more)

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm, and we identify female-derived proteins that are enriched for energy metabolism. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to a broad audience of scientists and the general public. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, through its A1 domain. Platelet activation, in part, requires force, and we show that force can switch the A1 domain to a second state with faster binding kinetics. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease mutations, which are known to increase the effects of force. The mechanism is also relevant to other systems in which force switches a receptor to a second state with faster kinetics. The results are relevant to understanding the effects of force on other proteins, such as integrins, and to understanding the effects of force on the spread of infection. The results also suggest that the effects of force on the spread of infection may be more widespread than previously thought.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered efforts to understand the impact of viruses on human health. This study addresses this gap, and provides a resource for the community to study the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the potential of the HSRL to provide new insights into the ACI. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to provide a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth today is known to be strongly influenced by the amount of sunlight reaching the surface. This study provides an independent method for determining the temperature of the Earth’s surface in the past. The method used is to determine the thermostability of enzymes that are known to be active only at high temperatures. The results of this study suggest that the temperature of the Earth’s surface has decreased over geological time.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channels’ C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide a new perspective on the regulation of K+ channels and may help in the development of new drugs for treating diseases caused by abnormal K+ channel activity. Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a single protein, erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175), to bind to glycophorin A (GPA) on the surface of the RBC. We show that this interaction leads to a change in the biophysical properties of the RBC, which in turn reduces a critical energy barrier to invasion. This work suggests that the malaria parasite primes the RBC surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the malaria parasite invasion process and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of malaria. (Show more)

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic relations between words as it processes a sentence. However, there is no direct evidence that this process actually takes place. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, providing evidence for a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is consistent with a neural implementation of a left-corner parser. Our findings provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists. They also suggest that the brain may use a merge operation to build syntactic structures. This may be a fundamental process in the brain, and it may be important for understanding the causes of language disorders.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in a wide range of biological processes, including development and cancer. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are regulated differently, which may be important for tissue-specific regulation. This study provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms of the Wnt pathway and may lead to the development of new strategies for cancer therapy.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. Here we show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and dopamine neurons in the pars reticulata of the substantia nigra (SNc), as well as by dopamine neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the LH. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of obesity. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The ability of bacteria to fix nitrogen (N2 fixation) is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle. The ability of plants to induce this process in their symbiotic bacteria is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle. However, the ability of plants to control the activity of their symbiotic bacteria is limited. Here, we report the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to deliver biologically fixed nitrogen in agriculture, with the potential to improve crop yields and nitrogen use efficiency. This work also represents a key step toward the development of synthetic microbial consortia for the sustainable use of nitrogen in agriculture. (Show more)

The Peruvian Amazon is the most deforested region of the world, and the rate of deforestation is increasing. The Peruvian government has invested in remote-sensed forest monitoring, but the effectiveness of these systems in deterring deforestation is unknown. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the disease, but the global distribution of these vaccines remains a challenge. Here we report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response in mice. The role of ALK/Ltk in neural crest development is still controversial. Here, we provide evidence that ALK/Ltk is activated by secreted ALKAL proteins in vivo. We show that the ALKALs are expressed in the neural crest and that loss-of-function alleles of the zebrafish homologue lead to iridophore loss. Our results provide evidence for a role of ALKALs in neural crest development and suggest that ALKALs are potential therapeutic targets in neuroblastoma. This is the first report of a ligand–receptor complex in the nervous system. Our results provide a basis for further studies on the role of ALKALs in neural crest development and in cancer.

The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has been responsible for devastating outbreaks throughout human history. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have provided insights into its evolution and ecology, but the number of genomes are too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague and its potential adaptation to fleas. This work also highlights the importance of ancient DNA in understanding the history of pathogens. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support.

In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has released a large amount of C to the atmosphere. However, the extent to which this trend can be reversed is unknown. Here, we show that soil health management practices can increase soil C storage and the use of C by soil microbes. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester C and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural practices. The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We then created a risk ranking tool, SpillOver, that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a roadmap for the systematic identification of zoonotic threats and the development of strategies to prevent future pandemics.

Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main components of nectar is nectarines, which are colored compounds that are thought to be attractive to pollinators. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a convergent evolution of this trait in two other plant species, Jaltomata herrerae and Nesocodon, which are visited by hummingbirds. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is likely to be favored by pollinators. This work provides insights into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–pollinator interaction. (Less)

We present a study of the genetic ancestry of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had skull deformations in the 5th/6th century. We show that these women had a genetic ancestry that was not present in the men of the same population. We also show that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and control of emerging and reemerging infectious diseases. We used a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify the pathogens responsible for undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We found that vector-borne pathogens were the most common cause of undifferentiated febrile illness, but that underappreciated zoonotic pathogens were also common. Our findings highlight the importance of ongoing pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. This approach can be used to identify the most urgent public health priorities and to deploy rapid public health response. This work is important for the global community to better understand the regional pathogen landscape and surveillance of emerging pathogens.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a unique insight into the molecular mechanism of lagging strand synthesis and the dynamics of the pol δ holoenzyme. This study also provides a unique understanding of the role of the PCNA sliding clamp in the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. These findings will help us to understand the role of pol δ in human diseases and will also help in the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in biology. In this study, we report the development of an RNA-based system that can replicate and convert genetic information into functional molecules in the absence of proteins. This system is based on an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize RNA from an RNA template. The polymerase can amplify short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Furthermore, the polymerase can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Thus, the system can serve as a model for the origin of life and as a platform for the development of RNA-based technologies.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the residents of those neighborhoods. This may have important implications for urban planning and policy.

The clinical characteristics of COVID-19 are still unclear, and the treatment is still in the process of exploration. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can reduce mortality and improve the clinical symptoms of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper into intracellular pools is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis is unknown. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. Copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of xan BGC metabolites were demonstrated in vitro and in vivo. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which fungi control copper homeostasis and may have implications for the treatment of fungal infections. The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, on Mars is surprising because it is not a common mineral in the martian crust. The presence of tridymite in a laminated mudstone at the base of the martian crust is consistent with the formation of tridymite in a silicic volcanic environment. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary environment is consistent with the possibility that silicic volcanism occurred in the vicinity of the sediment source. The presence of amorphous silica and iron oxides in the same sample is consistent with the possibility that the sediment source was a region of acidic leaching. The presence of post-lithification minerals in the same sample is consistent with the possibility that the sediment was reworked and transported. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agricultural crops. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new conditions. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to Th17 cells are not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can give rise to cells that retain a predominantly IL-17A+ phenotype and are unable to induce colitis in recipients. These cells are dependent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Understanding the mechanisms that give rise to Th17 cells may lead to the development of new therapies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, the cells responsible for generating muscle movement. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, but also by genetic variants that do not cause disease. We report a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes, which are cells that support the survival of neurons. This method enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that can alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity in ALS. This will help to identify new therapeutic strategies for ALS. This method can also be used to study other diseases that involve astrocyte-derived toxicity. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of ticks is a complex community that is essential for the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. Here, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota of the vector tick Ixodes scapularis to more efficiently colonize the vector. We demonstrate that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota by inducing the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix, which is a critical barrier for Anaplasma colonization. These findings provide insight into the molecular mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota of their vector. They also suggest that targeting the tick microbiota may be a promising strategy for the control of vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds, as it is the key to understanding the origin of flight. However, the early evolution of the tail is poorly understood because of the limited number of known fossils. Here, we describe a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, the pygostylians, and show that this group originated early in the history of birds.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause. This work provides a new perspective on the role of water vapor in the climate system. It also provides a new avenue for understanding the role of water vapor in the evolution of our climate.
