Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and even yellow, orange, and purple. These colors are produced by pigments, but some animals have distinctive colors that are not produced by pigments. These colors are produced by the presence of high concentrations of certain molecules in the animal’s tissues. For example, the blue color of the skin of some fish is due to high concentrations of biliverdin, a molecule that is not produced by any known pigment. In this study, we show that the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also presents evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis in vertebrates.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The identification of factors that promote the growth of breast cancer cells in the hypoxic microenvironment could lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modifications on mRNA, and that ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α pathways. ALKBH5 expression increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a breast cancer stem cell factor, and the breast cancer stem cell phenotype. Thus, ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia, and ALKBH5-mediated demethylation of m6A on NANOG mRNA promotes the growth of breast cancer cells in the hypoxic microenvironment. These findings suggest that ALKBH5 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. (Show more)

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction and recovery dynamics. However, the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific role of RORα remains unclear. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 3.0 Å resolution. We find that the D614G mutation has led to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This work provides a basis for understanding the impact of the mutation on the structure and function of the spike and may inform the development of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an equilibrium, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir (1982) to the case of Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The chemical properties of atoms are of great importance in chemistry and physics. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms can be modified under pressure, and we propose a new scale of electronegativity and chemical hardness. We show that the new scale can be used to predict and explain many chemical phenomena, including the formation of unexpected compounds under pressure. Our work provides a new perspective on the chemical properties of atoms and their modification under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of wildfires, which can have important consequences for the global carbon cycle. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are highly uncertain, and the effects of human activities are difficult to disentangle. We show that human demography, rather than climate, is the main driver of changes in fire activity over the past century. This has led to a reduction in fire activity, which, in turn, has reduced warming. Our results suggest that climate change may be slowing global warming, but that human demography is still the main driver of fire activity. This highlights the importance of active fire management and the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel cycle that is linked to the maturation of the symbiosis. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. Our results suggest that the provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms may be a more general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. This may be particularly important in the context of the current global trend toward antibiotic resistance. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We draw on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. Our method is motivated by the need to understand the gendered nature of violent death narratives. We show that our method can be applied to a wide range of domains and that it can be used to identify latent patterns in text data. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We believe that our method will be of interest to researchers in a wide range of disciplines.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the Black Death in the 14th century, is one of the most devastating events in human history. The disease was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, for centuries before the first plague outbreaks in Europe. This suggests that the bacterium was repeatedly reintroduced into Europe, rather than being established by a single introduction. Our results provide evidence for the importance of climate in the spread of plague in medieval Europe. They also suggest that the bacterium was already present in Europe before the first plague outbreaks.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play a key role in the ecosystem. However, they are also a major prey item for sea stars, which are a major predator in the marine food web. In the Northeast Pacific, asteroids are currently experiencing a mass mortality event, which is associated with a virus. This study provides evidence that the virus is the cause of the disease and that it has been present in the marine environment for at least 72 y. This study provides important information for the management of this important ecosystem component. It also provides a model for the spread of viruses in the marine environment.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other cancers as well. (truncated)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher contribution of African males to Madagascar than of African females. Finally, we found that the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across Madagascar is not homogeneous, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several independent waves. These results provide a detailed picture of the history of Madagascar, and they have implications for the study of human evolution and migration. (Show more)

While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to reduce the time and cost of antibody development and may contribute to the development of a new generation of antibody-based therapeutics. Our approach may also be applied to other protein molecules, such as enzymes and receptors, to improve their function and broaden their applications. Agricultural production is a key driver of the global economy, and the ability to monitor crop status in space and time is critical to manage production and mitigate risks. Current systems rely on satellite imagery, crop models, and meteorological data, but have underutilized the information provided by crop experts. We show that the US Department of Agriculture Crop Progress and Condition survey, despite its subjective nature, captures the complexities of assessing the “status” of a crop better than any model or satellite retrieval. We propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the survey data and demonstrate how it can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our findings have important implications for the design of large-scale continuous monitoring systems.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, leading to a lack of understanding of the response of soil respiration to climate change across a range of ecosystems. Here, we present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration measurements, which provide a more comprehensive understanding of the response of soil respiration to climate change. Our results provide evidence that soil respiration may not increase in response to climate change in all ecosystems, and that the response of soil respiration to climate change may vary across the globe. This information is critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. (Less)

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it is marked by a gradual change in the environment and the lifestyle of the organisms. Here, we present a model of the molecular evolution of the plastid genome during the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis, is linked to the relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This model can be used to understand the molecular evolution of the plastid genome in other parasitic organisms. (Less)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was a stark reminder of the vulnerability of South Africa and other water-scarce regions to climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has been a major advance in the field of materials science. The first test explosion of a nuclear bomb, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, resulted in the fusion of surrounding sand, the test tower, and copper transmission lines into a glassy material known as “trinitite.” Here, we report the discovery, in a sample of red trinitite, of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2. It represents the oldest extant anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, with the distinctive property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history. Like the naturally formed quasicrystals found in the Khatyrka meteorite and experimental shock syntheses of quasicrystals, the anthropogenic quasicrystals in red trinitite demonstrate that transient extreme pressure–temperature conditions are suitable for the synthesis of quasicrystals and for the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems. The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in multiple sclerosis (MS) and other neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in the pathogenesis of neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation, and that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the roles of ASK1 in the pathogenesis of EAE and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. The 2012–2014 California drought is the driest on record and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of co-occurring warm conditions has increased. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests that the forgetting process is a potential therapeutic target for autism. This study also provides a model system for studying the role of the forgetting process in learning and memory. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results offer the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but they also serve to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, and mutations in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 cause severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which result in hematological abnormalities and muscle pathology. Our data suggest that modulation of the CRAC channel activity may be a promising therapeutic approach for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. This study expands our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and suggests new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. In these diseases, the spread of aggregates is thought to be a major contributor to disease pathology. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell autonomous and that the spreading of aggregates can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis. These results demonstrate that the spread of aggregates is a major contributor to disease pathology and that the spread of aggregates can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis. This work provides a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of these diseases. Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. By selectively inhibiting the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection, MTX inhibited the antiviral responses of the host and facilitated viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The results also highlight the importance of the submandibular salivary gland as a potential site for virus spillover from bats. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. One-carbon units are used to support cell growth, and thus are critical for cancer. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in cancer cells blocks tumor growth in vivo. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, and show that they are effective in cancer cell-lines and xenograft tumors. However, one-carbon donor formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. This work provides a rationale for the use of formate as a cancer therapeutic. It also provides a platform for the development of cancer-specific inhibitors of SHMT. This would be of interest to the cancer community, as well as to the broader metabolomics community. The latter because SHMT is a key enzyme in the metabolism of serine, and thus a key metabolic pathway. The former because SHMT is a key metabolic target in cancer.

The presence of coaggregating proteins in the intracellular inclusions of ALS patients has been a subject of debate for many years. Here, we show that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of the three proteins that are mutated in ALS, but rather that the coaggregating proteins are even more supersaturated than the native interaction partners. This suggests that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is a consequence of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is a consequence of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. This may have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The earliest flowering plants were aquatic plants, and the study of these plants is important for understanding the origin of the flowering plants. The study of Montsechia, an early flowering plant from the Cretaceous, is important for understanding the origin of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to both the scientific community and the general public. In this study, we present the first ancient viral sequences from human remains, which provide insights into the evolution of human parvovirus B19. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)

Sea level is a key indicator of climate change. In this study, we use a 25-y time series of satellite altimeter data to estimate the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level. We find that the acceleration is quadratic in time, which implies that the rate of sea level rise is increasing. This is the first time such an acceleration has been estimated from satellite altimeter data. Our results suggest that the rate of sea level rise could be as high as 3.3 ± 0.4 mm/y by 2100, compared with 2.9 ± 0.4 mm/y over the last 25 y. This is in agreement with the IPCC AR5 model projections.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of this defining species. This study highlights the power of the integrated application of solid-state NMR, X-ray crystallography, and first-principles computational chemistry to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity. This approach offers a powerful tool for understanding the catalytic mechanism of enzymes and provides a means to predict the reactivity of enzyme substrates and inhibitors. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is caused by a zoonotic coronavirus, which has a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog inhibitor of viral replication, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This suggests that remdesivir may be a useful treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses. It may also be considered for a wider range of viruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of benefit in the context of a clinical trial for 2019-nCoV. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a clinical trial for MERS. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of benefit in the context of a clinical trial for 2019-nCoV.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel cycle that is linked to the maturation of the symbiosis. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This work provides a new example of the use of host-derived nutrients to regulate the activities of symbiotic microorganisms. It also suggests that other hosts may use this strategy to regulate the activities of their own symbionts. (Less)

This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The study also shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline are a powerful predictor of student outcomes, including suspensions. Finally, the study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. This work has implications for the future of education, including the design of scalable interventions to reduce suspensions and improve student outcomes.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the function of DNA. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is a major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions and is a leading cause of biodiversity loss and water pollution. The food choices of the world’s population are a key driver of this problem, and there is a need for effective interventions to encourage more sustainable diets. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can have a large impact on meal selection behavior. This approach could be used to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals served in a wide range of settings, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces. Our results suggest that it may be possible to achieve a 50% reduction in meat consumption in the UK by simply increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals offered in catering outlets. This would have a major impact on the environment and population health.

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment, and is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use quantitative proteomics to show that the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion by oncogenes, and that this remodeling is driven by the MAPK pathway. We also show that the surfaceome is remodeled by oncogenes in a cell-type specific fashion, and that this is reflected in the glycoproteome. These studies provide a systems-level view of how oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in breast cancer cells, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer biology and drug resistance. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or overall turnout. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is unlikely to have a significant impact on the 2020 presidential election.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a global pandemic, with the development of vaccines and therapeutics being the primary focus for the scientific community. However, the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a. This provides insight into the molecular basis for the unique immune evasion and evasion of the host interferon response seen in SARS-CoV-2. These findings provide a foundation for the development of new therapeutics to combat the spread of the disease. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying this condition are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia triggers cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of vascular networks. However, the development of vascular ECs is difficult to achieve in vitro. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the development of vascular ECs from human adult skin fibroblasts. This study provides a new strategy for the development of vascular ECs and may lead to the development of a new treatment for vascular disorders. Furthermore, the use of ETV2-expressing cells for vascular network formation in vivo may lead to the development of a new treatment for vascular disorders in vivo. This study provides a new strategy for the development of vascular ECs and may lead to the development of a new treatment for vascular disorders. (Show more)

The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are a family of transmembrane receptors that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. In addition, they are implicated in cancer and other diseases. In the present study, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between the RTKs and their ligands. We show that the zebrafish genome contains three genes that encode ligands for the RTKs, and that these ligands play an important role in pigment development. Furthermore, we demonstrate that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, which are specialized cells in the eye that are involved in color vision. These experiments establish a physiological link between the ligands and the RTKs and demonstrate that the ligands are essential for the differentiation of iridophore cells. This work provides insights into the function of RTKs and their ligands in vivo. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. Moreover, STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of β-cell function and insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of T2D and suggest that STING might be a potential target for the treatment of T2D. This study also provides a new perspective for the study of STING in other tissues and diseases. (Show more)

The influenza A virus is a single-stranded RNA virus that infects mammals and birds. It is responsible for an annual influenza pandemic and occasional pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging of the genome into virions. We identified a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion. This mechanism is essential for optimal viral replication. We also identified a sequence-dependent interaction between the viral RNA segments, which favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses is limited. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral packaging and might help in the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The atheroprone disturbed flow is a key environmental factor that promotes the development of atherosclerosis. However, the mechanisms by which disturbed flow induces the atheroprone phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells remain largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a key event in the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. In addition, we show that statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, inhibits YAP/TAZ activation and attenuates the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerosis. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides insights into the mechanisms of disturbed flow-induced vascular inflammation and atherogenesis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen dramatically in the United States in recent decades, and climate change has been implicated as a driver of this trend. Here, we show that the expansion of the human-caused fire season and geographic niche is a major driver of this trend. Our findings highlight the importance of human activities in increasing wildfire activity and suggest that actions to reduce wildfire risk should focus on reducing human-caused ignitions. These actions should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. (Less)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the residents of those neighborhoods. This may have important implications for urban planning and policy.

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insect bites. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in insects remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated that dTRPγ ion channel in Drosophila melanogaster is a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents to mediate avoidance behavior. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This study is also relevant to the COVID-19 pandemic, as the virus is transmitted by arthropods. Thus, our findings may help in the development of new strategies for the control of both the virus and the arthropods. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune response and the virus’s life cycle in the pathogenesis of the disease is being investigated. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment on the time to viral clearance. We also provide estimates of the parameters of the model, which can be used to inform future studies. The model can also be used to predict the effect of the virus’s life cycle on the disease’s severity. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a widespread phenomenon that is considered a key indicator of the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying causes of the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic activity of the coral host is the primary driver of the functional breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, which in turn increases the metabolic energy demand of the coral host. This energy limitation and altered symbiotic nutrient cycling form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the mounting of immune responses, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our study provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate the balance between host and microbial homeostasis and tumorigenesis. It also identifies a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of intestinal tumors. This study also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients will experience recurrence or metastasis. In this study, we show that the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is expressed in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). Furthermore, we show that ROR1 expression is associated with the enhanced capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is marked by a rapid warming and sea-level rise, with many climate changes attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. We show that a unique, ∼192-y series of volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which plausibly triggered a series of climate changes extending from Antarctica to the subtropics. This provides a unique link between the start of deglaciation and the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, and suggests that the start of deglaciation may have been triggered by human activities. This is an important step toward understanding the causes of the past and future climate changes. (Less)

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in conservation and sustainability assessments. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. Our data can be used to inform conservation and sustainability efforts, as well as to identify regions where freshwater fisheries can contribute to food security. Our analysis also reveals the high stakes for improving fishery management, as intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate after injury, and this inability is a major obstacle to the repair of CNS damage. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the adult C. elegans nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of factors that control the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. Moreover, our study suggests that the mammalian CNS may have a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK pathway. This possibility is supported by the observation that the mammalian CNS is able to regenerate after injury, and this regeneration is similar to the C. elegans DLK-independent regeneration.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key parameter in the evolution of the genome and of organisms. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we find that the distribution of recombination rates is similar to that in yeast and in mice. We also find that recombination rates vary in a polarity across genes, with higher rates at the start of genes than in the middle and at the end. These results provide a detailed view of the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and they suggest that the polarity of recombination is a conserved feature of eukaryotic genomes.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to reflect the underlying anatomical connections. However, the functional organization of the brain is not directly accessible to neuroimaging. Here, we used metabolic imaging to identify and validate the resting state organization of the brain in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects was similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic network expression in cerebral blood flow scans acquired during task performance. We found that the dominant network was deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a direct measure of the functional organization of the brain, and opens the way to the development of new imaging techniques for the study of brain function.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is known to regulate translation. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes, which we call the NAD+ cap. We show that NAD+ cap-containing mRNAs are found in both the nucleus and mitochondria. We also show that NAD+ cap-containing mRNAs are produced cotranscriptionally. These results suggest that the NAD+ cap may regulate mRNA stability and/or translation. Our findings provide insight into the function of the NAD+ cap and the mechanism of its production. They also suggest that the NAD+ cap may be a general feature of eukaryotic mRNA. (Show more)

The study of epigenetic mechanisms has been a focus of interest in the field of diabetes research. In this study, we show that DNA methylation patterns at specific loci in blood cells are altered in people with diabetes and that these alterations persist over time. We also show that these DNA methylation patterns are associated with glycemia, supporting an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These results provide a better understanding of the mechanisms of diabetes complications and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The role of a protein in cancer is determined by its function in the tumor microenvironment. Here, we show that the expression of a cancer antigen, FSIP1, is associated with poor prognosis in breast cancer patients. We also show that FSIP1 is a negative regulator of chemotherapy sensitivity in TNBC. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This study also provides a platform for further exploration of the role of FSIP1 in other cancers. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with high morbidity and mortality. The mechanisms of the disease are not fully understood, but it is generally accepted that it is a brain disorder. In this study, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence.

The tomato is a model system for studying the biosynthesis of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in plants. However, the VOCs produced by tomato fruit are highly variable, and the biosynthetic pathways of many of these compounds are not known. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the VOCs in tomato fruit. We also describe the use of this gene as a tool to identify the nitrogenous precursors of these VOCs. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of VOCs in tomato fruit and will be of interest to researchers studying the VOCs of other plant species. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most important drivers of ecosystem function, and because the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key determinant of ecosystem resilience. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. We also show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance curves of species. Our results have important implications for our understanding of the impacts of climate change on ecosystem function.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub in the hippocampus, where it receives information from the hippocampus and neocortex and sends information to the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex. The organization of MEC is important for understanding how information is represented in the brain and how it is used for navigation and memory. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are important for navigation, are organized separately from other cell types. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC and will be useful for understanding how information is represented in the brain. Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of the host and the parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering and flowering regulation. It also provides a new approach to understand the evolution of parasitic plants. This study may also provide a new approach to understand the evolution of flowering in plants.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The disease is characterized by the loss of dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra and the progressive loss of motor function. The cause of the disease is unknown, but it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system within the dopamine-containing nigral system that is affected in Parkinson’s disease and other disorders. We suggest that this system is critical to the function of the nigral dopamine system in health and disease. Our findings may lead to the development of new approaches to the treatment of Parkinson’s disease and other disorders of the dopamine system.

We are constantly interacting with others, and we often judge the quality of our interactions by how well we feel connected to each other. But how do we know when we are feeling connected? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust and honest signal of how connected we feel. This signal is used by others to judge the quality of our interactions, and it is used by us to signal how connected we feel. This work suggests that we are constantly judging the quality of our interactions, and we are constantly judging the quality of others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is also responsible for maintaining a stable heart rate under normal and pathological conditions. The SAN is a highly organized cell population, and the electrical activity of the SAN is controlled by a complex interplay between the membrane and the store-operated Ca2+ entry pathway. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the store-operated Ca2+ entry pathway in SAN cells. We also show that STIM1 regulates the electrical activity of SAN cells by controlling the activity of the store-operated Ca2+ entry pathway and the plasma membrane ion channels. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the control of SAN function. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore resistance has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to protect rice from insect herbivory. This study also provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of Si-mediated insect herbivore resistance. (Less)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings have important implications for our understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and for the development of new therapeutic strategies for diseases involving ether lipid metabolism. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for successful delivery and gene silencing. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. The impact of nutrient loading on the coastal zone is often overlooked in the context of large water bodies. We show that the majority of nutrient loading to the world’s fifth largest lake, Lake Michigan, comes from small tributaries. These findings have important implications for coastal eutrophication, as the nutrient inputs from small watersheds are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. Our results suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small watersheds to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This approach could be applied to other large water bodies, such as the Gulf of Mexico, to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on coastal ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a system of particles in a random potential, which is known to exhibit a phase transition between a high-temperature phase where the particles are uniformly distributed and a low-temperature phase where the particles are concentrated in rare regions of space. We find that the network dynamics are analogous to the dynamics of the particles in the random potential, and we discuss the implications of this analogy for the nature of the network dynamics. We also discuss the implications of our results for the study of the dynamics of complex networks in a biased environment.

The mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain, which in turn can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We validate a dynamic model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and show that the same changes in microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in the mouse model of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs and may help to explain the diverse range of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same changes in microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in other autoimmune encephalitis models. This may help to explain the diversity of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs. Finally, our findings may help to identify biomarkers of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. This could lead to the development of new diagnostic tests and the identification of new therapeutic targets.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical forest loss, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we use a comprehensive dataset of RSPO-certified and noncertified oil palm plantations (∼188,000 km2) in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil, as well as annual remotely sensed metrics of tree cover loss and fire occurrence, to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire from 2001 to 2015. The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The study of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. Sex determination is a fundamental aspect of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study in developmental biology. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a fish species with polygenic sex determination. We find that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics may be a general feature of polygenic sex determination. This modularity may also be a general feature of sex determination in animals, and may be a useful concept for understanding the evolution of sex determination in other species. (Less)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of lipofuscin, a complex of autofluorescent bisretinoids and other species. The role of iron in these processes is unknown. We show that the Fe chelator deferiprone decreases the accumulation of bisretinoids in the retina of albino mice. We also show that the bisretinoid A2E is oxidized and degraded by light and Fenton chemistry in cell-free assays. These findings suggest that iron may promote the oxidation and degradation of bisretinoids in the retina. This may contribute to the photodamage of the retina and may provide a target for therapeutic intervention. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and thus, their evolution is of great interest to ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered a dead end, as morphological and functional optimizations are often required to capture different prey types. Here, we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, have evolved modularity in their prey-capture system, and that this modularity is linked to the evolution of their prey. Our findings suggest that the evolution of predator specialization is not only possible, but also linked to the evolution of modularity in prey-capture systems. These findings contribute to a broader understanding of the evolution of predator specialization and its impact on food webs. They also provide insights into the evolution of morphological innovations and diversification of ecological niches.

The human hand is a complex and highly evolved structure. The evolution of the human hand has been linked to the emergence of modern human-like stone tool use, but the origins of the distinctive features of the human hand are poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has important implications for the origins of modern human hand morphology and for the evolution of Neandertals. (Less)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. One-carbon units are used to support cell growth, and thus are critical for cancer. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in cancer cells blocks tumor growth in vivo. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, and show that they are effective in cancer cell-lines and xenograft tumors. However, one-carbon donor formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. The world is facing a double burden of malnutrition, with a growing number of people suffering from undernutrition and a lack of access to adequate food, and a growing number of people suffering from overweight and obesity. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by having access to natural landscapes such as forests. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of modern agriculture, allowing for the expansion of food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the discovery of a new species of sauropod in Patagonia, Argentina
